YELLOTT TO HEAD
1931 JUNE WEEK
Edwin Lockard, President
of the Junior Class, announced
yesterday that John Yellott
had been appointed Chairman
of the 1931 June Week Committee. The appointment of
the remainder of. the committee will take place at a later
date.
Frederick Warring, President of the Class of 1930, appointed Yellott as a member
of this year's committee simultaneously.

COLLEGE CAMPUS BARBER SHOPS
PERFORM DIVERSIFIED SERVICES
Barbor shops have almost as
many and as curious uses as that
nominal contradiction, the drug
store. And these strange uses are totally aside from the ancient ones of
blood-letting and tooth-drawing. As
an organ for the dissemination of
news and a center of discussion it
enjoys a long-established reputation,
though one recently altered by the
bobbed-hair mode.

Tuesday a new role was foisted
upon the faithful John, Homewood
exponent of the tonsorial art. Not
satisfied with using his newspaper,
the next-store neighbors have made
him unofficial information bureau.
As might be expected, the business
staff was at the bottom of the matter. A well-known instructor in the
University telephoned the office to
inquire the hour of the HampdenSydney debate that night. A member of the business staff received
the call, and not possessing the information sought, resorted to poor
John. Unfortunately, that dignitary
couldn't help, so the business staff
member suggested to the teacher
that probably eight was the hour of
the debate.

JAY TO APPEAR
BEFORE MID YEARS
The next issue of The
Black and Blue Jay will appear between Wednesday 22
and Friday 24 of the current
month and of course, will be
the last number of the semester. This will be an "Out-ofDoors" number. The cover
design, which will be drawn
by Harold Bloom, will deal
with out-door sports. One of
Bryan Quirk's usual portrayals of a fair female will
adorn the publication. This
issue will consist of 36 pages
and will contain the usual
"Around the Campus," Passing Out," and "Seen from the
Pit" in addition to a number of
original new features.

The evils of the present system are two: first, many men are required
to take five, or even six, examinations on successive days; second,
students are often required to take two tests on the same day. When
a man takes his exams on successive days, he has not enough time to
study for each one and, consequently, all must suffer. There is a facile,
but hardly valid, objection to this statement. It is that students should
prepare for the quizzes during the weeks preceding January 27, but in
the case of the average student much reviewing must be done immediately before the examination, in order that the details of the course
may be retained in the memory during the fateful three hours. Everyone who has written a good examination paper only to forget many of
the answers within a short time after his mark has been posted, will
appreciate the necessity of a concentrated review a few hours before his
fate is to be determined. Furthermore, five examinations in five days is
a severe nervous strain, so that a man is quite apt to do very poorly on
the fifth day. We do not consider the physical strain involved since it
is a function of the first point, namely that not enough time is allowed
for review. The two vary inversely; if enough immediate review is
taken, the requisite rest and brain alertness suffer, if enough rest is
taken, the review suffers. But the nervous strain remains as no inconsequential difficulty. If one lifts his arm above his head, no strain is
felt; if it is done one hundred times without cease a terrific fatigue is
experienced; but if it is done twenty-five times, then a rest, then twentyfive more and so on until the hundred is completed, there is little strain
involved. So it is with exams; one is fine, but five in a row constitute
a temporary menace to the nerves. However, if a period of rest be given
between the quizzes, all would be comparatively smooth sailing. We do
not claim that exams constitute a menace to one's nervous system permanently, but we do state that the effect on the fifth day is noticeable,
even though recovery is very swift.
Two examinations on one day repeat all the evils of the five-in-fivedays case. Several years ago one of the professors in the undergraduate
school had made arrangements to leave the city before the date
scheduled for his examination. Consequently, the test was given on an
afternoon just two hours after the majority of the class had completed
another exam. It was on a particularly warm June day and we are the
authority for the statement that the studying for that examination consisted of utilizing every available shower in the Alumni Memorial Hall!
We now have eight days for examinations. Under the proposed
system there would be twelve. If the exams were spread over the entire
twelve-day period an advantage would be gained but there would still
be some unfortunates who, by the luck of the draw, would be forced to
take their tests in a hunch. We believe the better plan would be to designate four days on which no exams would be scheduled. The days for
working would then be:
First week—Monday, Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday
Second week—Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday.
Under this plan everyone would have at least one free day between
his exams and two days of holiday would intervene before the opening
of classes for the next term.
What would be best under this plan? In mid-years, classes that fall on
Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday would miss a full week's lecture, it is
true. Classes that come the first three days of the week would be deprived of one period only. Saturday classes are too few to be of any
great consequence. In the finals in June, absolutely no time would be
lost, as college would be in session three days longer. Surely the loss
of time in mid-years is hardly commensurate with the gain in fairness.

The evils of the present system are two: first, many men are required
to take five, or even six, examinations on successive days; second,
students are often required to take two tests on the same day. When
a man takes his exams on successive days, he has not enough time to
study for each one and, consequently, all must suffer. There is a facile,
but hardly valid, objection to this statement. It is that students should
prepare for the quizzes during the weeks preceding January 27, but in
the case of the average student much reviewing must be done immediately before the examination, in order that the details of the course
may be retained in the memory during the fateful three hours. Everyone who has written a good examination paper only to forget many of
the answers within a short time after his mark has been posted, will
appreciate the necessity of a concentrated review a few hours before his
fate is to be determined. Furthermore, five examinations in five days is
a severe nervous strain, so that a man is quite apt to do very poorly on
the fifth day. We do not consider the physical strain involved since it
is a function of the first point, namely that not enough time is allowed
for review. The two vary inversely; if enough immediate review is
taken, the requisite rest and brain alertness suffer, if enough rest is
taken, the review suffers. But the nervous strain remains as no inconsequential difficulty. If one lifts his arm above his head, no strain is
felt; if it is done one hundred times without cease a terrific fatigue is
experienced; but if it is done twenty-five times, then a rest, then twentyfive more and so on until the hundred is completed, there is little strain
involved. So it is with exams; one is fine, but five in a row constitute
a temporary menace to the nerves. However, if a period of rest be given
between the quizzes, all would be comparatively smooth sailing. We do
not claim that exams constitute a menace to one's nervous system permanently, but we do state that the effect on the fifth day is noticeable,
even though recovery is very swift.
Two examinations on one day repeat all the evils of the five-in-fivedays case. Several years ago one of the professors in the undergraduate
school had made arrangements to leave the city before the date
scheduled for his examination. Consequently, the test was given on an
afternoon just two hours after the majority of the class had completed
another exam. It was on a particularly warm June day and we are the
authority for the statement that the studying for that examination consisted of utilizing every available shower in the Alumni Memorial Hall!
We now have eight days for examinations. Under the proposed
system there would be twelve. If the exams were spread over the entire
twelve-day period an advantage would be gained but there would still
be some unfortunates who, by the luck of the draw, would be forced to
take their tests in a hunch. We believe the better plan would be to designate four days on which no exams would be scheduled. The days for
working would then be:
First week—Monday, Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday
Second week—Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday.
Under this plan everyone would have at least one free day between
his exams and two days of holiday would intervene before the opening
of classes for the next term.
What would be best under this plan? In mid-years, classes that fall on
Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday would miss a full week's lecture, it is
true. Classes that come the first three days of the week would be deprived of one period only. Saturday classes are too few to be of any
great consequence. In the finals in June, absolutely no time would be
lost, as college would be in session three days longer. Surely the loss
of time in mid-years is hardly commensurate with the gain in fairness.

There are obvious reasons why
industrial work is a valuable experience to any college student. Not
only does he earn money—which in
some instance, to be sure, may be
very helpful—and does he become
acquainted with the devious
mechanisms by which jobs are distributed, but he also meets face to
face with a new aspect of life, the
industrial aspect. These are no
longer the dry, lifeless considerations of industry which were formerly dished out to students in textbooks of economics.
"Once upon a time," Mr. Ludwig reminded us, "economics was
dreaded by students as 'the dismal
science.' But this is no longer true.
Today we have learned to combine
the study of statistical charts with
real, live experiences—and textbooks in economics even have pictures in them now." Thus, for instance, some colleges send their
students of economics out into the
industrial world to work for large
concerns, where they will have firsthand information as to how industrial plants are run and where they
will also become personally acquainted with the workers in industry, with their mode of working
and living and with their outlook
upon life.
One of the chief handicaps with
which the student is confronted in
industry is his lack of skill. To be
sure, the unskilled positions are
open to him, but as an unskilled laborer he is excluded from the trade
unions and, Mr. Ludwig believes,
an acquaintance with the unions
should prove a valuable experience
for a student. But even if the student can acquire the skill necessary
to handle more complicated machinery, there are so many skilled workers out of jobs, that the chances of
the student grow increasingly
smaller.
